inlineContent.text: One
instance stored in a global lifecycle context can manage multiple MIDI ports
and connections, and is usually sufficient for all of an application’s MIDI needs.
For SwiftUI and Combine environments, see the
subclass which adds
published devices and endpoints properties.
Create an instance of
within a lifecycle scope that makes sense for your app.
Typically MIDI functionality is scoped at an app-level since only one Manager is needed for an entire application’s MIDI needs.
A
instance can be stored globally, perhaps in your
or root SwiftUI
Parameters:
is an internal name used only to identify the manager instance to Core MIDI
is the user-visible model name of your app that is included in the meta-data of virtual ports you create
is the user-visible manufacturer, or company name of your app that is included in the meta-data of virtual ports you create
Typically a single

instance can handle all MIDI I/O needs for an entire application. It is fully encapsulated however, and it is possible to have more than one instance but even very large and demanding MIDI applications should still only require a single instance.
Once the manager instance is created, you must call
before you can create and connections or ports. Subsequent calls to
have no effect after it is first successfully called.

Typically you should only start the manager once, usually at app launch or when MIDI services are first required in your application. The Manager will dispose of itself and all of its ports and connections upon
Do not destroy and create new
s during the lifecycle of your application. This is not harmful but it is unnecessary.
All cleanup is done automatically in MIDIKit and no specific methods are required to be called before application termination.
will dispose of itself and all of its owned virtual ports and connections
When removing individual ports or connections from a
, they will dispose of themselves

topicSections.title: Accessing Created Ports and Managed Connections

abstract.text: Ports and managed connections created by the
can be accessed from these
properties. The keys of the dictionaries correspond to the
parameter that was passed when creating them.
Remove one or more ports or managed connections from the
Thru connections are a native feature of Core MIDI that can pass MIDI events from outputs to inputs directly.
Devices contain entities, and entities contain endpoints. Endpoints can be inputs or outputs. For most use cases, simply accessing
will be sufficient as it contains all possible endpoints in the system.
Central MIDI Port and Connection Manager and MIDI system data provider.
MIDI input and output endpoints in the system.
This is an observable implementation of
Dictionary of MIDI output connections managed by this instance.
MIDI Client Name.
Remove a managed MIDI endpoint or connection.
Core MIDI I/O wrapper layer offering
class to create virtual ports and connect to existing ports in the system in order to send and receive MIDI events.
Initialize the MIDI manager (and Core MIDI client).
MIDIKit umbrella import that includes all MIDIKit modules.
Dictionary of virtual MIDI outputs managed by this instance.
Core MIDI Client Reference.
Dictionary of non-persistent MIDI thru connections managed by this instance.
Array of persistent MIDI thru connections which persist indefinitely (even after system
reboots) until explicitly removed.
Removes all unmanaged persistent MIDI thru connections stored in the system matching the
given owner ID.
Handler that is called when state has changed in the manager.
Handler that is called when state has changed in the manager.
Central MIDI Port and Connection Manager and MIDI system data provider.
MIDI Model: The name of your software, which will be visible to the end-user in ports
created by the manager.
MIDI devices in the system.

dictionary of the
MIDI devices in the system.
Preferred underlying Core MIDI API to use as default when creating new managed endpoints.
This value defaults to the best API for the current platform.
Certain objects and properties are observable.
Remove all managed MIDI endpoints and connections.
Starts the manager and registers itself with the Core MIDI subsystem.
Call this method once after initializing a new instance.
Subsequent calls will not have any effect.
Tag selection for managed input/connection operations.
Managed port or connection type.
Dictionary of MIDI input connections managed by this instance.

MIDI Manufacturer: The name of your company, which may be visible to the end-user in ports
created by the manager.
Adds a new managed virtual input to the
dictionary of the
and creates the MIDI port in the system.
Specify a handler to receive Core MIDI system notifications.

Virtual MIDI ports (endpoints) can be created in order to allow the user to send your app MIDI events or receive events that your app sends. These will appear in the system to other software as MIDI ports, similar to physical MIDI ports.
Adds new a managed virtual output to the
dictionary of the
Creates a new MIDI play-through (thru) connection.
Managed connections are smart MIDI connections owned and maintained by the
. They form connections to one or more endpoints and automatically reconnect if the target endpoints disappear and reappear in the system.
MIDI input and output endpoints in the system.
Dictionary of virtual MIDI inputs managed by this instance.
